doc.title: Bernstein Energy & Power: Reshaping the Oil Services Industry - the 2000-50 journey (Part 1: The Golden Age: 2000-14)
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Bernstein Energy Power Reshaping the Oil Services Industry - the 2000-50 journey Part 1 The Golden Age 2000-14Bernstein _2025-08-29

passages.text: The recently announced \(\) 13.6bn\(acquisition of Chart Industries (NC) by Baker Hughes (NC) is a symptom of a wider trend: Oil Services companies are now reducing their (more cyclical) O&G exposure. Over a longer timespan, we would break down the Oil Services industry's 2000 - 50 journey into four periods.
The Golden Age (2000- 14). This period was dominated by the shale oil revolution and the beginning of deepwater oil.

The Great Disruption (2015- 24). Amid a very tough environment, Oil Services companies cut back their capital intensity massively, while embarking on the from- scratch development of new 'energy transition' offerings/technologies.

The New Era (2025- 34). Central to this period is a paradox: Oil Services companies are making long- term cuts to their O&G exposure, while visibility over the next 5 years for deep- water O&G and LNG has never been so good. CCUS, geothermal and data centers are also gaining traction/scaling up.

The Age of Circularity (2035- 50). Textile and plastic recycling will scale up. Having been highly successful in moving up their value chains/developing new value- added offerings, E&C companies - and in particular Technip Energies & Maire Tecnimont - look to be the best positioned to reap more than their share of this new revolution. Hence, a provocative question: will E&C companies also become B2C companies in 2040s?

This Part 1 covers the first period, i.e. The Golden Age (2000- 14). Subsequent blasts will cover the second, third and fourth periods, i.e. the Great Disruption (2015- 24), the New Era (2025- 34) and the Age of Circularity (2035- 50).

The lessons of the past are a great way of understanding - and reshaping! - the future. But before we do that - thanks to a 'good summer read' for the recent past, and by looking at oil services strategies for the 2000- 14 Golden Age - let's first look at the present situation, which is all about de- correlation. Having started in mid- 2022, the de- correlation between the cumulative market cap of the 60 largest energy services companies (c. \(\) 415bn\(and the oil price has widened further in 2025.
EXHIBIT 1: Oil services market capitalization (\$415bn) vs Oil Price: the de- correlation with oil price continues to widen
Source:BBG,Bernstein analysis & estimates

We could also raise a naive question by simplistically comparing the ytd share price performance of SLB (- 7%) and Baker Hughes (+8%): do investors structurally prefer to invest in energy services stocks with lower O&G exposure?

Coincidentally, and with the recently announced \(\) 13.6bn\(acquisition of Chart Industries (NC), Baker Hughes (NC) continues its long - term journey by repeatedly reducing its oil exposure. We view this acquisition as a symptom of the new era - even if it may also prompt other energy services companies to also accelerate their own oil exposure.

EXHIBIT 2: Oil Services (OFSE) was 63% of Baker Hughes' revenue in 2021, and would have been 52% of 2025 revenue standalone. With the planned acquisition of Chart Industries, OFSE might only be 45% of revenue. Does this mean Baker Hughes would still be an 'oil services company'?
(IET = Industrial & Energy Technology) Source: Baker Hughes; Bernstein analysis
Let's now head back into the past with a good summer read!
Unlike John Evans, CEO of Subsea 7, we are simply unable to read c.40 new business books every year.
We rather read two business books per annum. Note the differences. As far as reading is concerned, we prefer to follow Nassim Taleb's ("The Black Swan", "Antifragile") two pieces of advice.
1. Don't read too many books - instead, read a few good books again and again.

2. Build your own 'Umberto Eco library'. Italian writer Umberto Eco (1932-2016) was known for his very large personal library. A good library needs to be large (in order to provide 'optionality'). This optionality is enhanced if you can proudly claim not to have read 99% of the books in your library!
EXHIBIT 3: Exhibit 3 - Umberto Eco (1932- 2016) is the author of the Name of the Rose and Foucault's Pendulum. He was also famous for his extremely large library.
EXHIBIT 4: Is Max McKeown's The Strategy Book the best book on strategy?

A good summer read is Max McKeown's The Strategy Book. Over 24 small chapters (6- 7 pages max), it offers a list of theoretical concepts and practical ideas. It helps you think by asking again and again the seven (obviously open) strategic questions:

1. Where are we now?  
2. Where do we want to be?  
3. What must we do?  
4. How must it be done?  
5. How can we measure our progress?  
6. Why are we doing that? What is stopping us?  
7. What should we do now?
We have already written about strategy and oil services by distinguishing between "classical" and "modern" strategies.

- Classical strategies relate to market share, sustainable competitive advantages, ROCE or Porter's five forces. Classical strategies therefore generally work best for established, rich, traditional industries with long cycles, predictable demand and cash flows, and high barriers to entry. The focus here is on the long term. Classical strategies work well for traditional Oil & Gas companies

- Modern strategies (Prahalad, Hamel, Kim) place the premium on creativity/discovery/disruption. This can require taking someone else's ideas and developing them further, solving a customer problem, spending a day in your customer's shoes, or simply trying, trying and trying again. The focus here is on the medium term.

Big Oil companies are rich enough to pursue essentially classical strategies, but this is much less clear-cut case for oil services companies. On the one hand, they generally all aspire to pursue some kind of classical strategy. On the other, given their highly variable cash flows across the cycle, some of them (Petrofac, Viridien, etc.) have experienced profound disruption. In such cases, they had no other option than to reinvent themselves from the ground up.

The picture below depicts our strategy arrow. It goes from 0 = pure modern strategy to \(10 =\) pure classical strategy. A score of 0 is not negative per se (just as a score of 10 is not positive per se). QBL strategy arrow simply shows that most oil services companies are essentially pursuing a classical strategy.
EXHIBIT 5: Rich companies = classical strategy? QBP companies = modern strategy?
Source: Bernstein analysis & estimates

The most important characteristic of this Golden Age was the new dominance of National Oil Companies (NOCs) over Integrated Oil Companies (IOCs). NOCs only owned \(20\%\) (vs \(80\%\) for IOCs) of the world's O&G available reserves at the beginning of the 1970s. This percentage had increased to \(80\%\) (vs only \(20\%\) for IOCs) at the beginning of 2000s. And, crucially, this dominance of NOCs (over IOCs) is set to remain a major theme up to 2050.

The second main characteristic of this Golden Age was the nearly fivefold increase in E&P capex. The graph below, taken from an old note, shows that while E&P capex was essentially stable over the 1976- 2002 period (i.e. in the \(90 - 150bn\) p.a. range), it increased sharply to \(200bn\) in 2004 before jumping further to \(700bn\) in 2014. We are unlikely to see such levels again anytime soon. After \(600bn\) in 2024, our own estimate suggests c. \(560bn\) in 2025.
Source: Bernstein analysis & estimates

The graph below, from an old OECD report, shows that in order to meet this increased E&P capex, oil services companies have essentially pursued asset- heavy strategies and have invested in new assets. The previous asset boom was in 1982 (as an aftermath of the two oil shocks in the 1970s). Massive new capex plans (Seadrill, Saipem, Subsea 7, Technip) were launched in the early 2005- 2006 and translated into peak asset deliveries over 2008- 14.
Annual deliveries of offshore assets (rigs, supply vessels, construction vessels...) since 1970
Source: OECD, Bernstein analysis

The rise of fracking (= liquid injections to force open existing fissures to extract O&G) and intelligent completions (= pressure and temperature sensors delivering real- time measurement and down- hole adjustments) have revolutionized the US (and world's) O&G landscape since 2006. OCTG players (Tenaris, Vallourec) have been the main beneficiaries, as this requires longer laterals as well as corrosion- resistant tubes.
EXHIBIT 8: US oil production & the rise of shale oil
Source: Rystad, Bernstein analysis

UDW - mainly in Brazil and in the GOM - started to contribute significantly around 2008. As far as UDW is concerned, oil services companies tried to answer two main questions during the 2000- 14 Golden Age:

How is it technically feasible to recover UDW oil? Will the subsea infrastructure (trees, manifolds...) be able to resist the pressure? Could flexible pipes also work at water depths of \(2000m\) - How is it economically feasible to recover UDW oil? Could integrated solutions (= engineering + equipment + installation) help reduce development costs?
EXHIBIT 9: Worldwide offshore oil production
Source:Rystad,Bernstein analysis

The 2000- 14 Golden Age came after decades of under- investment in both E&P projects and production assets (drilling rigs, FPSOs, subsea vessels). Looking back to 2005, many companies were aware that the average age of production assets was often \(>25\) years. In other words, oil services companies would have some pricing power as long as they could offer differentiated technologies and, even more importantly, differentiated new and state- of- the- art assets for which companies would be prepared to pay very high day rates \((>\) 700,000).
The market for oil services was very fragmented. Many new players entered (and disrupted) the market with a wide range of strategies.

Low- cost strategies - especially in the Middle East where new Asian contractors were bidding at very low prices. Established players also started to recruit significantly in countries with lower wages

Cultural/local content strategies - this is the case of Petrofac in the Middle East (and of all established players in the Middle East, Brazil and Western Africa) State- of- the- art assets, such as the fascinating stories of Seadrill and Bourbon, which became world leaders from scratch in less than five years

In growing - but fragmented - markets, it is of course always tempting to opt for some kind of horizontal M&A (e.g. Subsea 7 and Acergy, which became Subsea 7 in 2011). This is often a poor strategic decision as it is generally the other players that take advantage of this consolidation process. Our view is that horizontal M&A only makes sense in already somewhat oligopolistic markets (hence our positive view on the Saipem- Subsea 7 merger).

Seadrill was founded in 2005 in Bermuda (by Norwegian multimillionaire John Fredriksen) on share capital of \(\) 12,000\(, with the stated ambition of becoming the world leader in offshore drilling within five years.

At that time, the average ages of the world fleet for jack- up drilling rigs and semi- submersibles were 24 and 23.3 years, respectively. By being the first to order new equipment, Seadrill secured three advantages over competitors: 1) time, as shipbuilders are now fully booked, leading to delays to orders from Seadrill's competitors; 2) price, thanks to grouped orders; 3) and of course the advantage of having one of the most modern fleets in the world.

But Seadrill's main characteristic is first and foremost the daily quest for financial optimisation (the annual reports make for instructive reading in this respect) whether in terms of: 1) investment, with accelerated rotation of physical and financial assets; 2) financing (leverage, convertible bonds, asset sale and lease- backs, minority shareholders at different levels of the capital structure, the listing of least profitable assets); 3) shareholder returns (tax rate below \(10\%\) , yield above \(10\%\) ). We note that John Fredriksen and the managers of Seadrill bought shares in October 2024.
EXHIBIT 10: Mission statement: creating a world leader with 5 years
EXHIBIT 11: In 2006, Seadrill already had 19 rigs (vs 0 in early 2005).
EXHIBIT 12: 69 rigs by the end of 2014 i.e. at the end of the Golden Age

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI) index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non-Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:

Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp- Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 10\) pp- Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12- month time horizon.
